description: In this tutorial, we show how to perform a structural relaxation using our Web Interface, for the simple case of a total energy calculation performed on crystalline silicon.
title: Exabyte.io Tutorial: Perform a Structural Relaxation

youTubeCaptions.text: Create a simulation, by navigating to the job designer page.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> inside the materials tab, choose a slightly distorted version of silicon as the main simulation material, by selecting it in the list.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> open the workflow tab, and insert the relaxation add-on. A new 'variable-cell relaxation' subworkflow will hence be added.
Now, open the only unit component of this subworkflow.
Inspect the Quantum ESPRESSO input file displayed at the bottom. <break time='1.0' /> Notice the 'vc-relax' input keyword, specifying the variable-cell relaxation nature of the calculation.
After that, <break time='0.5' /> navigate to compute tab, and set compute configuration. Here, we use one node with four cores.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> set the name for the job. <break time='2.0' /> Here, we call it - Silicon Structural Relaxation.
Next, <break time='0.5' /> save the job. <break time='5.0' /> It can then be selected and submitted to the compute queue, for execution.
The status of the calculation will change from pre-submitted to submitted, and then to active.
When the job is finished, open it, to inspect the final results.

Under the results page, note the graphic visualization of the final relaxed crystal structure. <break time='5.0' /> Its crystallographic numerical parameters can be exported to the local disk, in the <sub alias='POSH CAR'>POSCAR</sub> format, and inspected via a text editor.
Notice also how the inter-atomic forces and the stress tensor of the final structure are both nearly zero, as expected for a relaxed configuration.
